title.narrative: Nigeria Joint Response 2021 - WASH and FS/Cash in Monguno and Biu

description.narrative: In 2021, the North-East Nigeria crisis is going into its twelfth year. The crisis remains one of the most severe in the world. Continued widespread insecurity and hostilities, especially in Borno State, continue to have serious consequences on humanitarian operations and the civilian population. ZOA provides the most vulnerable groups amongst IDPs families with lifesaving food (multipurpose cash)  and safe drinking water and sanitation (WASH) services to help them meet their basic needs and live a healthy life.  The project is being implemented in Biu and Monguno LGAs.  In Biu ZOA is collaborating with SCI  which implements child protection and FSL while ZOA implements WASH and Cash.  In Monguno the FSL support from ICCO/JDPH, is complemented by ZOA with Cash, while WASH is included for the community.

description.narrative: ACCR1 - ACCR1 Participation

title.narrative: ACC-I1 - Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

description.narrative: ZOA will engage beneficiaries, community leaders and LGA stakeholders in project processes including registration and selection of beneficiaries; post distribution monitoring, community feedback meetings, complaints and feedback system, etc.

comment.narrative:
The 690 individuals (57% women) reached comprised of recruited community nutrition mobilizers, hygiene promoters, community committee members, lead mothers, community leaders, PDM respondents and average CFM participants.
The CNMs, HPs and the lead mothers are stakeholders directly involved in the implementation of the project while the community committees and the community leaders do participate in the monthly community feedback meetings to give inputs and opinions about project activities and equally support project monitoring during post distribution monitoring.
ZOA considered persons with disability, specifically their participation in project implementation activities. Ten (11) persons with disability across the two project LGAs were recruited to join implementation. These include two (2) Hygiene promoters (M-2), one (2) Community Nutrition Mobilizer (F-1) (M-1) and six (6) Community committee members (F-2, M-4).

comment.narrative: During one of the CFM session in Monguno, participants requested that Friday distribution should only be for one community because Friday use to be a very busy day for them. ZOA welcomed the suggestion and adjusted the distribution period accordingly. During the farming season, hygiene promoters beneficiaries requested for the adjustment of time to to when they return from farming to participate in hygiene promotion in Biu. This was adopted and implemented.

title.narrative: CSHR1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: CSHR1 - CSHR1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: CSH-I1 - Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: 3,935 individuals will receive multipurpose cash. Of this number, 2,355 will be referred by SCI in Biu. These individuals will receive five rounds of monthly cash representing 70% (NGN4,860) of the minimum expenditure basket that is currently used in Monguno under NJR2020. Other beneficiaries could be referred by other protection actors in Biu. In Monguno, 1,580 individuals will receive 7 rounds of monthly per capital transfer representing 100% of the multisectorial MEB.

comment.narrative:
Multi-Purpose Cash The reporting period covers a target of 4,105 individuals (823HH) for Multipurpose cash (1,750 in Monguno and 2,355 individuals in Biu). As of December 2021, 4,844 individuals (862HH) were reached with cash support in Monguno and Biu against the initial target. Of the numbers reached, 54% are females, and 46% are males. Monguno: COVID-19 top-up from 2020 carried over to 2021: A total of 330 individuals (108HH) received one round of cash transfer in the month of January 2021 in Monguno with NGA 4,010 of per capita.
ZOA area of operation: 1,362 individuals (352HH) from Julari and Veterinary IDP camp. These individuals also received 9 months of cash transfer with NGA 6,940 per capita. Of the 1,362 individuals are individuals with protection concerns referred by PUI last year under NJR2021 still received the Nine (9) months cash support. ICCO/JDPH (25% referral): A total of 403 individuals (90HH) initially referred by ICCO/JDPH individuals received Nine (9) months transfer with NGA 6,940 of per capita.
Biu: 3,079 individuals (420HH) received 6 months of transfer with NGA 4,010 per capita all referrals from SCI for cash support from four communities: Buba, Mapi, Yawi and Vikutha. The initial planned was for 5 months of transfer but because of the exchange gain, an additional round of disbursement was served to all 3,079 individuals.

title.narrative: WSH-R1 Hygiene Promotion

description.narrative: WSHR1 - WSH-R1 Hygiene Promotion

title.narrative: WSH-I1 - Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Distribute 3,400 hygiene kits to benefit 17,000 individuals in Biu LGA (2,400) and Monguno LGA (14,600). Contents of hygiene kits will be in line with the WASH sector recommendation on kits composition.

comment.narrative: ZOA distributed a total of 4,167 hygiene kits (118% of target) in Biu and Monguno (3,552 in Monguno and 493 in Biu). In both locations, 17,707 individuals (4,499 boys, 5,088 men, 5,516 girls and 2,604 women) benefitted from the hygiene kits package. ZOA registered and distributed hygiene kits to 1,720 households or 7917 individuals (1685 boys, 2970 men, 2806 girls and 456 women). In line with the project design to provide hygiene kits to 25% or 732 individuals with protection concerns, ZOA received referrals of 815 households or 3,869 individuals (1,148 boys, 806 men, 1,046 girls and 869 women) with protection concerns from JDPH in Monguno. ZOA also prepositioned emergency hygiene kits package to respond to emergency situations. During the course of the project, ZOA distributed 1,139 hygiene kits representing 5,921 individuals (1,666 boys, 1,312 men, 1,664 girls and 1,279 women) to new arrivals and victims of fire incidence in Kuya IDP camp, GSSSS, Fulatari and Waterboard IDP camps.

title.narrative: WSHR2 Excreta Disposal

description.narrative: WSHR2 - WSHR2 Excreta Disposal

title.narrative: WSH-I2 - Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Rehabilitation of 385 stances of latrines (285 in Monguno & 100 in Biu) and rehabilitation of 210 stances in Monguno to benefit targeted communities

comment.narrative: ZOA constructed and rehabilitated 425 stances/compartments (370 in Monguno and 55 in Biu) of latrines in both locations. This is estimated to benefit 8,500 individuals using the Sphere standard of 20 persons per latrine. ZOA supported both communities with latrine construction and rehabilitation. In Monguno, ZOA constructed 50 new stances (25 communal and 25 household) of Improved Ventilated Pit (VIP) latrines estimated to benefit 1,000 persons. 370 Latrines under poor conditions were assessed and rehabilitated in Monguno to provide access to clean and decent sanitary conditions. This was estimated to benefit 7, 400 persons including women and children. In Biu, ZOA only constructed 55 new latrines stances in four villages (Buba, Mapi, Vikhuta and Yawi) where the needs are most. 1,100 individuals are expected to utilise these facilities. Community members were trained to provide operation and maintenance services. All sanitation facilities fulfil SPHERE standards including lockable doors, ramps and handrails to ensure safe access and privacy for women and people with disabilities.

title.narrative: WSH-I6 - Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: 4,250 individuals in Biu will receive hygiene promotion while 10,975 individuals from Kuya Camp and Julari host community will benefit from hygiene promotion. Hygiene promotion in locations targeted by ICCO/JDPH are the responsibility of other WASH partners in those locations as per the rationalization arrangement.

comment.narrative: ZOA conducted hygiene promotion activities to through community-based hygiene promoters and supervisors. In both locations, ZOA reached 18794 individuals (6229 boys, 5613 girls, 3077 men and 3875 women. A total of 55 hygiene promoters (25 males, 30 females) were recruited and trained to conduct hygiene promotion in Biu and Monguno. Of this number, 45 were in Monguno while 10 are in Biu. In addition, 7 hygiene promoters supervisors (3 females, 4 males) were recruited to supervise activities of hygiene promoters. There are five (5) HP supervisors in Monguno and two (2) in Biu. In Monguno, a national organization, Sanitation and Hygiene Education Initiative (SAHEI) handles the hygiene promotion component. During the rainiy season in August, ZOA, through its implementing partner increased the number of hygiene promoters by 15. This was to increase awareness sessions and campaigns due to the Cholera epidemic reported in other LGAs in Borno state. ZOA utilizes various methods of disseminating information which includes posters, banners, public address systems, flipcharts etc. This has proven to be effective as individuals who do not read can easily understand messages displayed as images and shared as sound.
